cyclone.name: MATTHEW
cyclone.current_location: about 275 miles SW of Port-au-Prince, Haiti
cyclone.trajectory: moving northward, forecast to accelerate and recurve toward the north-northwest, skirting the Bahamas mid-week and then approaching the southeast U.S. coastline (FL–GA–SC) late Friday into Saturday
cyclone.expected_landfall_location: possible close approach/landfall along the southeast U.S. coast near the GA-SC border

weather_observation.watch_coast: None in effect for U.S. coastline as of this advisory
weather_observation.warning_coast: None in effect for U.S. coastline as of this advisory
weather_observation.impacted_coast: Entire southeast U.S. shoreline from Florida through the Carolinas is within the 5-day cone, including the South Carolina coast
weather_observation.wind: Tropical-storm-force winds (39–57 mph) are currently given a 22% cumulative chance; a slight westward track shift could bring stronger gusts or even hurricane-force winds to the port.
weather_observation.storm_surge: If Matthew hugs the coast, surge of 3–6 ft above normal tides is possible in Charleston Harbor and adjacent waterways.
weather_observation.rainfall: Heavy rain bands associated with Matthew could deliver 4–8 inches, producing flash-flood potential and fresh-water runoff issues for port facilities.
weather_observation.other_hazards: Very rough seas, dangerous rip currents, coastal erosion, and possible channel shoaling that could restrict vessel transits before and after the storm.
